Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186,.proposition: Plaintiff files this Complaint seeking damages and statutory relief for Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186, section 14, due to failure to maintain habitable conditions and allowing persistent mold to exist in the unit, thereby substantially interfering with Plaintiff’s tenancy and health.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, as this matter involves a civil action for damages arising from a landlord-tenant relationship.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.750.proposition: The continued presence of mold constitutes a violation of sanitary code standards under 105 C.M.R. §410.750, which requires landlords to maintain premises free from chronic dampness and mold.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment by acts or omissions causing the premises to be uninhabitable or unfit violates the tenant’s statutory rights and is liable for damages.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to actual and statutory damages, including up to three months’ rent or three times actual damages, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs as provided by G.L. c. 186, §14.

State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410).proposition: Declare that Defendant must remediate the mold and ensure the premises comply with the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410); and

*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when a landlord’s failure to correct known defects seriously interferes with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and explains that it is violated by serious interferences with the tenant’s tenancy, including a landlord’s omissions where the natural and probable consequence is interference with use of the premises. The opinion applies this to Gem’s failure to correct known flooding defects, holding that allowing repeated, preventable flooding that interfered with Solomon’s use of her apartment breached the duty underlying quiet enjoyment under G.L. c.186, § 14. This aligns with the proposition that failure to correct known defects that seriously interfere with beneficial use constitutes a breach.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights…. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: The statute protects tenants from conditions created or allowed to persist by a landlord that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment—and cannot collect rent—when conditions that materially interfere with tenants’ use (here, extreme bar noise) are the natural and probable consequence of situations the landlord created and had the ability to control, even without wrongful intent. The opinion emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct in introducing and permitting a noisy lounge to operate near residential units, and allowing the condition to persist despite control rights, resulted in premises that were not reasonably habitable, thereby protecting tenants from such conditions.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable… There are occasions… where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: Failure to maintain a habitable dwelling and violations of the **State Sanitary Code** constitute interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion’s core holding is about lead paint and quiet enjoyment, but in explaining § 14 the court cites prior cases, including Dorgan v. Loukas, and characterizes that case as involving a landlord’s ‘failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so’ as a violation of § 14. That discussion recognizes that failure to maintain a habitable dwelling and related State Sanitary Code defects can amount to negligent interference with quiet enjoyment. However, this is done by way of citation and summary, not as a primary holding in this case, so the support is indirect rather than central.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.proposition: Failure to maintain a habitable dwelling and violations of the **State Sanitary Code** constitute interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly grounds the tenant’s remedy in breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the presence of substantial State Sanitary Code violations, but it addresses rent abatement and not interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14. The court discusses the Sanitary Code as defining the landlord’s minimum duties and as a measure of habitability, not as automatically constituting interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus the case supports the proposition that Code violations can constitute a breach of the warranty of habitability and justify rent abatement, but not that they constitute interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855 (1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remove mold and correct the underlying ventilation defect, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with the beneficial use of the premises, and thus a breach.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion deals extensively with heating failures, widespread sanitary code violations, harassment, and general uninhabitability, but it does not mention mold, ventilation defects, or failure to remediate those specific conditions. While the case supports the broader idea that serious, uncorrected conditions can breach the warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment, it is not authority for the specific proposition that failure to remove mold and correct ventilation problems constitutes a substantial interference and breach. Thus, using this case for that narrow mold/ventilation proposition would be inaccurate.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855 (1.relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.

*Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remove mold and correct the underlying ventilation defect, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with the beneficial use of the premises, and thus a breach.
*Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion does address breach of the warranty of habitability but contains no facts or discussion about mold, ventilation defects, or a landlord’s failure to remedy those conditions after notice. The court only notes that there were various sanitary code violations and that most had minimal impact on use and enjoyment, and then upholds a lump-sum damages award without elaborating on any particular condition. It therefore does not establish the specific principle that unremedied mold and ventilation problems constitute a substantial interference with beneficial use amounting to a breach.
*Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code...have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment... Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability... The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations. There is record support for the amount awarded."

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417 Mass. 273 (1994)**
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.proposition: Massachusetts courts hold landlords liable when omissions result in unsafe, unsanitary, or unhealthy conditions within rental units.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.support_reasoning: The court expressly rejects expanding the warranty of habitability to cover nonphysical conditions like crime and security and confines that warranty to physical facilities and conditions measured by building and sanitary codes. It also limits nuisance and discusses quiet enjoyment in terms of serious interference, not generally imposing liability for all unsafe, unsanitary, or unhealthy conditions resulting from omissions. Thus, the opinion does not stand for a broad rule that Massachusetts courts hold landlords liable whenever omissions result in unsafe, unsanitary, or unhealthy conditions; it narrows such liability rather than expanding it.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.… Our conclusion in no way affects the existing liability on the part of landlords under negligence theories… We also note that a landlord can be held liable for personal injury resulting from a breach of the warranty of habitability.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts hold landlords liable when omissions result in unsafe, unsanitary, or unhealthy conditions within rental units.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service required by the State Sanitary Code—constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and warrants declaratory, injunctive, and damages relief. Heat goes directly to the safety, sanitation, and healthfulness of a dwelling, so this case is clear authority that landlords are liable when their omissions (here, not providing heat) result in such substandard conditions in rental units. The court also rejects financial inability as a defense, reinforcing the landlord’s duty to maintain habitable, code-compliant conditions.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to … an injunction ordering that heat be provided in compliance with the State Sanitary Code….”

*Winchester v. Seay*, **394 Mass. 581 (1.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment applies regardless of whether the landlord’s interference is intentional or results from negligence.
*Winchester v. Seay*, **394 Mass. 581 (1.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court case about the libel-proof plaintiff doctrine in a defamation suit, not about landlord‑tenant law or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It nowhere discusses quiet enjoyment, landlord interference, or whether that covenant applies to intentional versus negligent acts by a landlord. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposed landlord‑tenant proposition and appears to be a miscitation.
*Winchester v. Seay*, **394 Mass. 581 (1.relevant_excerpt:
We conclude that Jackson was libel-proof at the time of the publication and, therefore, affirm the summary judgment entered for the defendants.
...
This court has had little occasion to consider whether a particular libel plaintiff may have such a notorious reputation that he is incapable of recovering damages in a libel action, and, therefore, may be characterized as libel-proof.

*Jablonski v. Clemons*, **60 Mass. App..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment applies regardless of whether the landlord’s interference is intentional or results from negligence.
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, **60 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly holds that a landlord’s good-faith but ineffectual efforts do not provide a defense to a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, citing Cruz Management and Lowery. By rejecting a good-faith defense and focusing instead on whether the landlord’s acts or omissions seriously interfered with the tenancy, the court makes clear that liability under the covenant does not turn on intentional misconduct versus negligence, but on the effect of the interference.
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, **60 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: While it is true that the property manager made several attempts, albeit ineffectual, to correct the problem, there is no good faith defense to a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 788-790; Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982). ... A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363.proposition: The existence of mold, which is inconsistent with the **warranty of habitability** under *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363 Mass. 184 (1973)**, also constitutes a violation of quiet enjoyment, as multiple courts recognize that substantial code violations and health hazards are actionable interferences.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurring/dissenting opinion focused on adopting and defining an implied warranty of habitability and its relationship to housing codes and rent obligations. It does not discuss, apply, or link these habitability/code-violation issues to the separate doctrine of breach of quiet enjoyment, nor does it say that such conditions constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that code violations or mold that breach the warranty of habitability also constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363.relevant_excerpt: “The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally, (b) that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations, and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him.”
